name: Linux SysManual
description: Essential Linux commands and tools for system administration

entries.name: ls
entries.notes: Combine options: -lah shows detailed, human-readable list with hidden files

entries.name: cd
entries.notes: ~ represents home directory, . is current directory, .. is parent directory

entries.name: pwd

examples.description: Display full path of current directory

entries.notes: Useful when you're lost in the directory structure

entries.name: cp

details.label: -u
details.value: Update: copy only if source is newer

entries.notes: Always use -r when copying directories, or you'll get an error

entries.name: mv

content.Purpose: Move files to new location or rename them

examples.description: Move all .txt files to documents folder

entries.notes: mv works across filesystems - cp then delete would be two operations

entries.name: rm
entries.notes: DANGER: No undo! Files are permanently deleted. Never run 'rm -rf /' as root!

entries.name: mkdir
entries.notes: Use -p to avoid errors when parent directories don't exist

entries.name: touch
entries.description: Create empty files or update timestamps

examples.description: Update modification time of existing file

entries.notes: If file exists, touch only updates the timestamp without changing content

entries.name: ln
entries.notes: Symbolic links can point to non-existent files; hard links share inode

entries.name: cat

examples.description: Display file and search for text

entries.notes: Good for small files - for large files use 'less' or 'head/tail'

entries.name: less
entries.notes: Better than 'more' - allows backward scrolling and searching

entries.name: head

examples.description: Show first 5 lines of all log files

entries.notes: Useful for quickly checking file format or headers

entries.name: tail

content.Purpose: View end of files or follow logs

examples.description: Monitor web server access in real-time

details.label: -f
details.value: Follow file (show new lines as added)

entries.notes: tail -f is essential for monitoring logs - press Ctrl+C to stop following

entries.name: grep
entries.description: Search for text patterns in files

examples.description: Recursively search all files in directory

entries.notes: One of the most useful commands - essential for log analysis

entries.name: find
entries.description: Search for files by name, size, date, etc.

examples.description: Find all .txt files in current directory tree
Find files modified in last 7 days

details.label: -mtime N
details.value: Modified N days ago (-N = within N days)

entries.notes: Very powerful - be careful with -delete option, test search first!

entries.name: sed

content.Purpose: Find and replace text, edit files

entries.notes: Powerful for batch text transformations - test without -i first!

entries.name: awk

content.Purpose: Process columns and fields in text

examples.description: Print first column from each line
Use colon as separator, print usernames

details.label: NF
details.value: Number of fields in current line

entries.notes: Best for working with columnar data like logs, CSV files, or command output

entries.name: wc
entries.description: Word count - count lines, words, characters
entries.notes: Often combined with pipes to count results from other commands

entries.name: sort
entries.notes: Use with uniq for advanced deduplication

entries.name: uniq
entries.notes: Must sort first for non-adjacent duplicates

entries.name: nano

examples.description: Open or create file for editing

entries.notes: Recommended for beginners - shows all commands at bottom of screen

entries.name: vim
entries.notes: Very powerful but takes time to learn - run 'vimtutor' to learn basics

entries.name: chmod

examples.description: Recursively set permissions on all files

details.label: -R
details.value: Recursive (apply to all files in directory)

entries.notes: 755 for scripts/programs, 644 for regular files, 700 for private files

entries.name: chown

examples.description: Change only if current owner is root

entries.notes: Usually requires sudo - be careful with recursive operations

entries.name: umask
entries.description: Set default file permissions for new files
entries.notes: umask subtracts from 666 (files) or 777 (dirs) - e.g., umask 022 gives 644 for files

entries.name: lsattr / chattr
entries.notes: Even root can't delete immutable files until flag is removed

entries.name: top

content.Purpose: View CPU, memory, and process usage

entries.notes: Press 'h' inside top for help. Look at load average and memory usage

entries.name: htop
entries.notes: Much easier to use than top - shows CPU bars and uses mouse support

entries.name: ps
entries.notes: Use with grep to find specific processes: ps aux | grep processname

entries.name: kill
entries.notes: Try normal kill first - use kill -9 only if process won't stop

entries.name: df

examples.description: Show disk usage in human-readable format

entries.notes: Watch for filesystems near 100% - can cause system problems

entries.name: du

content.Purpose: Find which directories use most space

examples.description: Show size of each item in current directory

entries.notes: Use to find space hogs: du -sh /* | sort -h to see largest directories

entries.name: free
entries.notes: Don't worry if 'available' memory is low - Linux uses free RAM for cache

entries.name: iostat
entries.notes: Install sysstat package. Look at %util for disk saturation

entries.name: useradd / adduser

examples.description: Create user with home directory and bash shell

entries.notes: Use 'adduser' on Debian/Ubuntu (interactive), 'useradd' on RedHat/CentOS

entries.name: usermod

examples.description: Add user to sudo group (grant admin rights)

details.label: -aG group
details.value: Append to group (don't remove from others)

entries.notes: Always use -a with -G or you'll remove user from other groups!

entries.name: userdel

examples.description: Delete user and remove home directory
Force removal even if logged in

details.label: -r
details.value: Remove home directory and mail spool

entries.notes: Backup important data before using -r!

entries.name: groups
entries.notes: Groups control file access permissions - common groups: sudo, docker, www-data

entries.name: sudo
entries.description: Execute commands as another user (usually root)
entries.notes: Safer than logging in as root - user must be in sudo group

entries.name: apt (Debian/Ubuntu)

examples.description: Update package list from repositories (always run first!)

entries.notes: Always run 'sudo apt update' before installing or upgrading packages

entries.name: yum / dnf
entries.notes: dnf is successor to yum - same commands work

entries.name: snap
entries.notes: Self-contained packages - larger but work across different Linux distributions

entries.name: flatpak
entries.notes: Great for GUI apps - add flathub.org repo first

entries.name: uname
entries.notes: Useful for checking kernel version and architecture

entries.name: hostname
entries.notes: Hostname identifies your computer on the network

entries.name: uptime

content.Purpose: How long system has been running

entries.notes: Load average shows system load over 1, 5, and 15 minutes

entries.name: whoami

examples.description: Show original login name (even after su)

entries.notes: Simple command to check which user you're logged in as

entries.name: w
entries.description: Who is logged in and what they're doing

content.Purpose: Show logged-in users and their activity

entries.notes: Useful on multi-user systems to see who's logged in

entries.name: lscpu
entries.notes: Shows cores, threads, cache, virtualization support

entries.name: lsblk
entries.notes: Great for understanding disk layout

entries.name: tar
entries.notes: Remember: 'czf' to create, 'xzf' to extract. Add 'v' for verbose output

entries.name: zip / unzip
entries.notes: ZIP format is cross-platform - works on Windows, Mac, Linux

entries.name: gzip / gunzip
entries.notes: gzip only compresses single files - use tar for directories

entries.name: ip

examples.command: sudo ip addr add 192.168.1.100/24 dev eth0

entries.notes: Replaces ifconfig, netstat, route, arp

entries.name: ss
entries.notes: Faster and more powerful than netstat

entries.name: ping
entries.notes: Press Ctrl+C to stop. Look for '0% packet loss' for good connection

entries.name: traceroute / mtr
entries.notes: mtr combines ping + traceroute with real-time stats

entries.name: curl / wget
entries.notes: curl for APIs/scripts, wget for simple downloads

entries.name: dig / nslookup
entries.notes: dig is more powerful, nslookup is simpler

entries.name: nc / netcat

examples.description: Test if SSH port is open

entries.notes: Swiss army knife of networking

entries.name: systemctl
entries.notes: Most modern Linux uses systemd

entries.name: journalctl
entries.notes: Replaces traditional log files in /var/log

entries.name: tree
entries.notes: Install with: sudo apt install tree

entries.name: tmux
entries.notes: Survives SSH disconnects

entries.name: rsync
entries.notes: Faster than scp for large/incremental transfers

entries.name: watch
entries.notes: Press Ctrl+C to stop
